220.66.text:

234.67.text:

So the funny thing was I started doing some

263.55.text:
And it turns out that he actually got the

269.51.text: A review with the writer William Burroughs.

273.95.text:
Burroughs was talking about his cutup method
of writing in which he took a piece of existing

279.51.text:
text, cut into pieces and then rearranged

289.38.text:
What was interesting when I started researching

293.73.text: got the idea from his buddy Brion Gysin.

296.91.text:
Brion Gysin was preparing a canvas for one
of his paintings and he sliced through a stack

303.39.text:
of newspapers and he saw the way the strips

308.73.text: that came out from rearranging those strips.

311.82.text:
And what he thought was this might be an interesting

317.01.text:
But the more research I did, the more I found

322.31.text:
made poetry from the newspaper even before

330.05.text:
He walked up in a Paris theater with a hat

335.44.text:
pieces put the pieces in the hat and pulled
them out one by one and read them as if they

343.39.text: I traced things all the way back to the 1700s.

To a neighbor of Benjamin Franklins called

And what Whitefoord would do, back in those

So what Caleb Whitefoord would do is he would

364.87.text:
read the newspaper allowed but he wouldn't

And he would get all kinds of funny combinations

377.06.text:
So not only was my idea totally unoriginal

385.96.text: of finding poetry in the newspaper.

392.69.text:
Instead of stopping there I decided to keep
on and steal everything I could from those

399.47.text: people that had come before me.

402.90.text:
And that is where the second book comes into
play.

408.05.text:
Every artist gets asked the question where
do you get your ideas.

412.34.text: And the honest artist answers "I steal them."

416.63.text: How does an artist look at the world?

418.46.text: Well first you figure out what's worth stealing.

420.81.text: And then you move onto the next thing.

423.84.text: That's about all there is to it.

425.41.text:
And when you look at the world this way you
stop worrying about what's good and what's

431.79.text:
There is only stuff worth stealing and stuff
not worth stealing.

437.35.text:
Someone once asked David Bowie if he thought
himself to be an original.

440.88.text:
And he said, "No, not at all I'm more like
a tasteful thief".

445.81.text:
He said that the only art he'll ever study
is the stuff that he can steal from.

453.41.text:
Everything in the world is up for grabs with
this worldview.

456.21.text:
If you don't find something worth stealing
today you might find it worth stealing tomorrow

461.37.text: or a month or a year from now.

465.57.text:
The writer Jonathan Lethem, he has said that
when people call something original 9 times

470.62.text:
out of 10 they just don't know the references
or the original source material involved.

477.48.text:
There was another writer who said, "What is
originality?

483.24.text:
What a good artist understands is that nothing
comes from nowhere.

489.72.text: All creative work builds on what came before.

497.87.text: This itself is actually not a new idea.

500.46.text: It's right there in the Bible.

505.61.text:
"That which has been is what will be done
and there is nothing new under the sun."

510.71.text:
Now some people find this idea completely
depressing.

516.59.text: But for me it's always filled me with hope.

519.20.text:
As a French writer Andre Gide put it, "Everything
that needs to be said has already been said.

525.71.text:
But since no one was listening the first time
everything must be said again."

532.50.text:
See I think if we are free of the burden of

538.24.text:
trying to make something out of nothing and

545.12.text:
See I have this idea that every new idea is

554.67.text:

And then you draw another line parallel to

At first you think there's two, there's the

572.94.text:
But then if you look in between them, there
is a line of negative space running in between

578.88.text: One plus one sometimes equals three.

583.65.text:
And here's an example of what I'm talking

588.43.text: You have a mother and you have a father.

You possess features from both of them but
the sum of you [Video Skip]

594.97.text:
You're a remix of your Mom and Dad and all

601.26.text:
And just as you have a family genealogy you

606.52.text:
We don't get to pick our families but we can

609.92.text: And we can pick our friends.

631.95.text:

See you are in fact a mash-up of what you

The German writer Goethe says, "We are shaped

654.26.text:
I actually think, I think human beings are

663.95.text:
You see hoarders collect indiscriminately

668.81.text:
They only collect the things that they really

You're only going to be as good as the stuff

1155.81.text:

until you actually make something.

1166.98.text:

1232.75.text: Your props are your tools and your material.

And the best way I know of going about faking

1252.91.text: Now nobody is born with the style or a voice.

We don't come out of the womb knowing who

1258.64.text:
In the beginning we learn by pretending to

1263.94.text:
Now we're talking about practice here, not

1268.04.text:
Plagiarism is taking someone else's work and

1275.50.text:
It's like a mechanic taking apart a car to

1279.98.text: We learned to write by copying the alphabet.

1337.42.text:

You don't just steal from one of your heroes

you copy from one author its plagiarism.

1362.65.text: If you copy from many it's research."

you're influenced by everyone will say you're

But if you rip off 100 people everyone will

1390.08.text:

1998.69.text: So Kobe Bryant, he talks about.

2001.99.text:
Kobe Bryant is a really interesting basketball

2007.36.text:
that could actually watch tapes of other basketball
players playing.

2012.23.text: And they had like highlight reels and stuff.

2014.50.text: So Kobe Bryant talks about how he would copy.

2019.05.text:
He would watch these heroes of his and then
he would remember their moves.

2023.44.text:
And that when he got on the court he would
try to copy the moves.

2026.62.text:
But what he found was that he didn't have
the same body type as a lot of these guys.

2032.07.text:
And he didn't have the same teammates in the
same context.

2035.72.text:
So what he had to do was adapt those moves
into something that was actually his own.

2041.55.text:
Now what I think copying does for us is for
one thing it shows us our shortcomings.

2048.13.text:
Like 'cause you always fall short of your
heroes.

2050.56.text:
But what's interesting is the shortcoming
is almost what you're really good at.

2055.48.text: Like that thing that you are not.

2058.27.text:
The thing that you don't quite attain by copying
your heroes, it's almost because you are built

2062.85.text:
this other way and you need to figure out
what your move is.

2066.58.text:
So I actually think the best thing to do is
to survey.

2072.06.text: Is to do exactly what you said.

2073.61.text: It's to, use survey the history of your discipline.

2076.59.text: You survey what people are doing.

2078.75.text:
And then you figure out, there's a couple
of ways to make your own mark.

2083.02.text:
Like I think one thing to do is just to think
about what your heroes didn't make.

2089.11.text:
What did they not get to that you could get
to?

2093.57.text:

and they collaborated on something, what would

2099.17.text: Like what would they make you know?

2101.88.text:

2216.39.text:
But I've actually found that time management

thing as far as like doing the thinking and

2227.14.text:
Because like I've worked day jobs my whole

2231.31.text:
And I wrote my first book on my commute to
and from work.

2235.19.text: And in the basement on my lunch break.

2240.91.text:
I actually, and this book I wrote when I was

2244.35.text:
I actually recommend everybody's got different
times when they're more creative.

2248.85.text: Like some people are night people.

2250.26.text:
Some, I don't know anyone who's an afternoon
person but some people are morning people.

2255.56.text:
I actually recommend to young folks who have
day jobs, but they have like passion projects

2260.56.text: that they want to work on.

2261.91.text:
I say if you can swing it, become a morning
person because you wake up early and you sit

2268.73.text:
down and you get a good hour or an hour and
a half in.

2272.47.text:
And then when you go to your day job you've
already got that out of the way.

2276.94.text:

'cause it takes a lot of energy to do good

2283.09.text:
And I'm sure employers don't like it when
I say this but you know I think if you can

2287.73.text:
get the work you want to be doing, you really
want to be doing out of the way in the morning.

2293.09.text:
Then you know they can't take it from you
for the rest of the day.

2297.69.text: You just schedule that time you know.

2301.19.text:
That's the cool thing is like if you schedule

2308.14.text:
